Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art on sandstone cave wall, showing myriad painted, infilled human figures, mythical creature and bird. All human figures but for ‘swimming’ figures are upright, with the most prominent: At upper right depicted as if running to right, at centre, in red with white adornments at knee and ankle, heads cut off by flaking, and at upper right, both red and grey-green with further adornments. Crowd of smaller human figures in a line stand along base of image. mythical beast (mass of infilled torso intersecting with human figures) is at right centre. Several figures are horizontal with limbs contorted as if swimming. Wadi Sura, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: See also 2013,2034.11348. Wadi Sura (also spelled Sora) is a valley on the western edge of the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s western desert. There, two shallow caves lie on the right at the entrance to the inlet, one smaller than the other and both containing rock paintings. Hans Rhotert designated the caves C and D. Cave C is the larger and contains the paintings of the famous ‘swimming’ figures inspiring those in ‘The English patient’. Cave D, which is close by, contains a single scene of cattle and archers. These caves were discovered, and the valley named, in 1933 by László Almásy. There are several other rock art sites nearby, some discovered by Almásy and Rhotert in the same year, or by P. A. Clayton in 1931, and several which have subsequently been found and documented by Giancarlo Negro, Yves Gauthier, Werner Lenz, András Zboray, Werner Lenz and others.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
